questions.prompt: For F = <P, Q> in 2D, what is curl F?
questions.explanation: In 2D, curl F = ∂Q/∂x - ∂P/∂y (scalar representing the k-component of 3D curl)

questions.prompt: For F = <P, Q, R>, what is div F?
If curl F = 0 everywhere in a simply connected region, then F is conservative.
questions.explanation: In a simply connected region, curl F = 0 ⟺ F is conservative

options: Line integral around C to double integral over R
questions.explanation: Green's Theorem: ∮_C P dx + Q dy = ∫∫_R (∂Q/∂x - ∂P/∂y) dA

questions.prompt: Green's Theorem states ∮_C F · dr equals what (for F = <P, Q>)?
questions.explanation: Green's Theorem (circulation form): ∮_C P dx + Q dy = ∫∫_R (∂Q/∂x - ∂P/∂y) dA

questions.prompt: Stokes' Theorem relates a line integral around a closed curve to what?
questions.explanation: Stokes' Theorem: ∮_C F · dr = ∫∫_S (curl F) · n dS

questions.prompt: Stokes' Theorem is a generalization of Green's Theorem to 3D.
questions.explanation: Stokes' Theorem extends Green's Theorem from plane regions to surfaces in 3D space

questions.prompt: For F = <P, Q, R>, what is curl F?
The Divergence Theorem relates what two types of integrals?
options: Surface integral of F · n to triple integral of div F
questions.explanation: Divergence Theorem: ∫∫_S F · n dS = ∫∫∫_E div F dV

questions.prompt: The Divergence Theorem is also called Gauss's Theorem.
questions.explanation: The Divergence Theorem is also known as Gauss's Theorem or the Gauss-Ostrogradsky Theorem

questions.prompt: What is the physical interpretation of divergence at a point?
options: Rate of outflow per unit volume
questions.explanation: Divergence measures the "source strength" or rate of outflow of a vector field per unit volume

questions.prompt: What is the physical interpretation of curl at a point?
options: Rotation or circulation per unit area
questions.explanation: Curl measures the rotation or angular velocity of a vector field at a point

questions.prompt: If div F = 0 everywhere, the vector field F is called incompressible or solenoidal.
questions.explanation: A field with zero divergence has no sources or sinks (incompressible flow)

questions.prompt: For any vector field F, div(curl F) = 0.
questions.explanation: This is a fundamental identity: ∇ · (∇ × F) = 0 for any sufficiently smooth F

questions.prompt: For any scalar function f, what is curl(∇f)?
questions.explanation: Another fundamental identity: ∇ × (∇f) = 0, meaning the curl of a gradient is always zero
